title: Judge Criticizes Immigration Enforcement in Release of Father and Son
summary: A federal judge ordered the release of 5-year-old Liam Conejo Ramos and his father, Adrian Conejo Arias, from an ICE detention center in Texas by Tuesday. They were detained by immigration officers in Minnesota after the father allegedly entered the U.S. illegally from Ecuador. Judge Fred Biery harshly criticized the Trump administration's enforcement approach, citing a pursuit of deportation quotas that traumatizes children. The case gained attention due to images of Liam surrounded by officers and allegations that officers used him as 'bait' to lure his mother, though the Department of Homeland Security denies this. The father has a pending asylum claim, and their detention sparked protests and a visit by Congress members. Biery's ruling referenced historical grievances from the Declaration of Independence, comparing the administration's actions to oppressive tactics.

background_read: This article discusses U.S. immigration enforcement under the Trump administration, focusing on a case involving a father and son detained by ICE. Immigration policies often involve debates over enforcement methods, such as detention and deportation targets. Asylum claims provide a legal pathway for individuals fleeing persecution, but processing can be contentious. Federal judges play a key role in reviewing these cases for fairness and legality. The reference to the Declaration of Independence highlights concerns about government overreach and historical parallels to current issues.
